Appendix A Federated Learning

Federated learning (FL) collaboratively learns a global model Gùê∫G by iteratively aggregating the local model updates sent by the nùëõn clients selected during each training round. In each training round tùë°t, the global model server selects a total of nùëõn clients and sends them a common aggregated global model, Gt‚àí1superscriptùê∫ùë°1G^{t-1}. Then, each client i‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,n}ùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëõi\in\{1,\ldots,n\} locally trains a local model Witsuperscriptsubscriptùëäùëñùë°W_{i}^{t}, using its own local dataset Disubscriptùê∑ùëñD_{i}. After training the local model, each client iùëñi, sends the updated model parameters to the global server to compute the next stage global model, Gtsuperscriptùê∫ùë°G^{t}. In this paper, we assume the global server aggregates the local updates by utilizing Federated Averaging (FedAVG) function¬†[23], given as:

Gt=‚àëi=1nsis‚ÄãWit‚Äã,where‚Äãsi=‚ÄñDi‚Äñ‚Äãand‚Äãs=‚àëi=1nsiformulae-sequencesuperscriptùê∫ùë°superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùë†ùëñùë†superscriptsubscriptùëäùëñùë°,wheresubscriptùë†ùëñnormsubscriptùê∑ùëñandùë†superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùë†ùëñG^{t}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{s_{i}}{s}W_{i}^{t}\text{,}\quad\text{where}\,\,s_{i}=||D_{i}||\,\,\text{and}\,\,s=\sum_{i=1}^{n}s_{i}

FedAVG utilizes each client‚Äôs training dataset to compute the latest global model. A malicious client (or clients) can take advantage of this requirement by sending the erroneous dataset size¬†[42]. To eliminate this scenario, we assume equal weights (si=1/nsubscriptùë†ùëñ1ùëõs_{i}=1/n) for all the clients. Such an approach has also been adopted in previous research efforts¬†[3, 37, 45, 35].

Appendix B Background and Preliminaries

In this section, we provide brief technical background knowledge on Bayesian non-parametric modeling and related concepts, which will be critical in understanding the design of BayBFed.

B.1 Hierarchical Beta-Bernoulli Process (HBBP)

Next, we describe the concepts of the baseline Beta Process, the Hierarchical Beta Process, and the Bernoulli Process, which are used to compute the probabilistic measure.

Beta Process (BP). A Beta Process is a random discrete measure on the countable infinitely drawn set of weights, where each weight has a mass in the range (0,1) such that the total mass sums to 1. A Beta Process uses a concentration function cùëêc over some space Œ©=‚ÑùŒ©‚Ñù\Omega=\mathbb{R} and a base measure HùêªH to produce some random measure Aùê¥A, i.e., A‚àºB‚ÄãP‚Äã(c,H)similar-toùê¥ùêµùëÉùëêùêªA\sim BP(c,H). Given the set Œ©Œ©\Omega, informally, a measure is any consistent assignment of sizes to (some of) the subsets of the set. Depending on the application, the size of a subset may be interpreted as either its physical size or the probability that some random process will yield a result within the subset. Formally, a measure is a function Œº:Œ£‚Ü¶[0,‚àû]:ùúámaps-toŒ£0\mu:\Sigma\mapsto[0,\infty], where Œ£Œ£\Sigma is the œÉùúé\sigma-algebra (collection of subsets) of Œ©Œ©\Omega. A concentration function (cùëêc) quantitatively characterizes the scatter of the values of a random variable. Thus, it indicates the similarity between the input base measure (HùêªH) and the output random measure (Aùê¥A). The base measure HùêªH can represent any initial distribution (see¬†Sect.¬†4). We also call Œ≥0=H‚Äã(Œ©)subscriptùõæ0ùêªŒ©\gamma_{0}=H(\Omega) the mass parameter. So, if HùêªH is a normal distribution, then Œ≥0subscriptùõæ0\gamma_{0} is a normal distribution of the complete space Œ©Œ©\Omega. Alternatively, Aùê¥A is a discrete measure (discrete weights), represented by A=‚àëjaj‚ÄãŒ¥wjùê¥subscriptùëósubscriptùëéùëósubscriptùõøsubscriptùë§ùëóA=\sum_{j}a_{j}\delta_{w_{j}}, where Œ¥ùõø\delta is an indicator function. Thus, in order to draw an infinitely countable set of points (aj,wj)‚Üí[0,1]√óŒ©a_{j},w_{j})\to[0,1]\times\Omega needs to be drawn. The probabilistic weights {aj}j=1‚àûsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùëéùëóùëó1\{a_{j}\}_{j=1}^{\infty} are distributed by a stick-breaking process: dj‚àºB‚Äãe‚Äãt‚Äãa‚Äã(Œ≥0,1)similar-tosubscriptùëëùëóùêµùëíùë°ùëésubscriptùõæ01d_{j}\sim Beta(\gamma_{0},1), aj=‚àèk=1jdksubscriptùëéùëósuperscriptsubscriptproductùëò1ùëósubscriptùëëùëòa_{j}=\prod_{k=1}^{j}d_{k}. In a stick-breaking process¬†[32], there is a stick of length of 1 and ajsubscriptùëéùëóa_{j} represents the probabilistic weight taken from the remainder of the stick every time. wjsubscriptùë§ùëów_{j} are drawn independently and identically distributed (IID) from the normalized base measure wjsubscriptùë§ùëów_{j} ‚àºsimilar-to\sim H/H‚Äã(Œ©)ùêªùêªŒ©H/H(\Omega) with domain Œ©Œ©\Omega. Here, B‚Äãe‚Äãt‚Äãa‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùêµùëíùë°ùëé‚ãÖBeta(\cdot) represents the beta distribution that is used to model the continuous random variables in the range [0, 1]. This work assumes that Œ©Œ©\Omega is simply a space of weights. The objective here is first to draw a baseline Beta prior (random discrete measure) using a Beta Process and then use this prior (in a Hierarchical Beta Process, as explained next) to draw the corresponding Beta priors for the nùëõn entities.

Hierarchical Beta Process (HBP). A Hierarchical Beta Process (HBP) is used to create hierarchies of the baseline Beta process when certain conditions are satisfied. Alternatively, from a pool of countable infinite sets of weights of the BP, a subset of weights (under some conditions) are drawn for each sub-Beta Process, creating hierarchies. We can employ HBP to draw a discrete random measure corresponding to each of the nùëõn entities based on the baseline Beta Process prior¬†[41]. Let us consider the following rationale for the construction of the HBP. Thus, each WiP‚Äãr‚Äãi‚Äão‚ÄãrsubscriptsuperscriptùëäùëÉùëüùëñùëúùëüùëñW^{Prior}_{i} is generated by including h‚Ñéh weights (wùë§w) independently with a probability pwhsubscriptsuperscriptùëù‚Ñéùë§p^{h}_{w} specific to the entity iùëñi. The random measure Aùê¥A, thus, Ai,hsubscriptùê¥ùëñ‚ÑéA_{i,h}, encodes the probability that each entity possesses each particular weight.

Bernoulli Process (BeP). A Bernoulli Process (BeP) is a draw of weights from a space of total weights, given the Beta Process random measure that encodes the probability of selecting the weight in the draw. BeP is employed to draw weights given the Hierarchical Beta priors computed earlier. Thus, the subsets of points in the HBP prior Ai,hsubscriptùê¥ùëñ‚ÑéA_{i,h} are drawn using a BeP with input as the random measure Ai,hsubscriptùê¥ùëñ‚ÑéA_{i,h}. Each subset WisubscriptùëäùëñW_{i} for entity in i‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,n}ùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëõi\in\{1,...,n\}, having lùëôl weights, is characterized by a Bernoulli Process such that Wi|Ai,h‚àºBeP‚Äã(Ai,h)similar-toconditionalsubscriptùëäùëñsubscriptùê¥ùëñ‚ÑéBePsubscriptùê¥ùëñ‚ÑéW_{i}|A_{i,h}\sim\text{BeP}(A_{i,h}). Each subset can also be represented by a discrete measure such that the points (bi,l,wlsubscriptùëèùëñùëôsubscriptùë§ùëôb_{i,l},w_{l}) ‚Üí[0,1]√óŒ©‚Üíabsent01Œ©\to[0,1]\times\Omega, forms Wi=‚àëlbi,l‚ÄãŒ¥wlsubscriptùëäùëñsubscriptùëôsubscriptùëèùëñùëôsubscriptùõøsubscriptùë§ùëôW_{i}=\sum_{l}b_{i,l}\delta_{w_{l}}, where bi,lsubscriptùëèùëñùëôb_{i,l} is the probabilistic weight (success probability) given to wlsubscriptùë§ùëôw_{l}, i.e., P‚Äãr‚Äã(bi,l=1)=pwhùëÉùëüsubscriptùëèùëñùëô1subscriptsuperscriptùëù‚Ñéùë§Pr(b_{i,l}=1)=p^{h}_{w}, if they are included in the subset WisubscriptùëäùëñW_{i}.

Conjugacy. It has been shown in the literature that the Beta distribution is the conjugate of the Bernoulli distribution¬†[6]. Hence, we do not have to use the computationally intensive Bayes‚Äô rule to compute the posterior distribution of hierarchical random measures. It can be computed as follows: Let Ai,h‚àºB‚ÄãP‚Äã(ci,A)similar-tosubscriptùê¥ùëñ‚ÑéùêµùëÉsubscriptùëêùëñùê¥A_{i,h}\sim BP(c_{i},A), and let Wi|Ai,h‚àºBeP‚Äã(Ai,h)similar-toconditionalsubscriptùëäùëñsubscriptùê¥ùëñ‚ÑéBePsubscriptùê¥ùëñ‚ÑéW_{i}|A_{i,h}\sim\text{BeP}(A_{i,h}). In Wi={Wi,1,Wi,2,‚Ä¶,Wi,l}subscriptùëäùëñsubscriptùëäùëñ1subscriptùëäùëñ2‚Ä¶subscriptùëäùëñùëôW_{i}=\{W_{i,1},W_{i,2},...,W_{i,l}\}, lùëôl denotes the independent BeP draws over the likelihood function, Ai,hsubscriptùê¥ùëñ‚ÑéA_{i,h}. By using the results for HBP and BeP in¬†[17], the posterior distribution of Ai,hsubscriptùê¥ùëñ‚ÑéA_{i,h} after observing WisubscriptùëäùëñW_{i} is still a Beta process with modified parameters:

Ai,h|Wi‚àºB‚ÄãP‚Äã(ci+l,cici+l‚ÄãH+1ci‚ãÖl‚Äã‚àël=1lWi)similar-toconditionalsubscriptùê¥ùëñ‚ÑésubscriptùëäùëñùêµùëÉsubscriptùëêùëñùëôsubscriptùëêùëñsubscriptùëêùëñùëôùêª1‚ãÖsubscriptùëêùëñùëôsuperscriptsubscriptùëô1ùëôsubscriptùëäùëñA_{i,h}|W_{i}\sim BP\left(c_{i}+l,\frac{c_{i}}{c_{i}+l}H+\frac{1}{c_{i}\cdot l}\sum_{l=1}^{l}W_{i}\right) (9)

Our motivation is to first draw a baseline Beta Process random measure by drawing a countable infinitely set of weights, such that their probabilistic weight sums to 1. Then, we use this baseline Beta Process to form hierarchies of Beta Process for nùëõn different entities. We do so by selecting a subset of h‚Ñéh weights from the total weights space for each of the nùëõn entities. Then, for each of the nùëõn entities, we use Bernoulli Process to draw lùëôl weights from the corresponding hierarchical Beta Process weights space. Finally, we keep updating the corresponding hierarchical Beta Process for entity nùëõn using the conjugacy of the Beta Process and the Bernoulli Process [6].

B.2 Mixture modeling: Chinese Restaurant Process (CRP)

The CRP¬†[39, 5, 22] is a discrete-time stochastic process in the probability theory that resembles the situation of seating customers at tables in a Chinese restaurant with an infinite number of circular tables, each with infinite capacity. The first customer that arrives sits at the first table. The following customers can either sit at the already occupied tables or can choose to sit at the new table. This process partitions the customers among tables. The results of this process are exchangeable, meaning that the order in which the customers arrive and sit does not affect the probability of the final distribution. In CRP, we compute two probabilities for table (cluster) assignment. The first probability is the probability of the customer entering the restaurant and sitting at the already occupied tables (clusters). The second probability is the predictive probability of how well this new customer fits the mean of already occupied tables (clusters).

B.3 Jensen-Shannon Divergence

Jensen-Shannon Divergence or Jensen-Divergence is used to realize the distance between two distributions. Specifically, it is computed by estimating the relative entropy between two distributions. The entropy of a random variable XùëãX having probability mass function P‚Äã(x)ùëÉùë•P(x) is given as:

H‚Äã(X)=‚àí‚àëx‚ààXP‚Äã(x)‚Äãl‚Äão‚Äãgb‚ÄãP‚Äã(x)ùêªùëãsubscriptùë•ùëãùëÉùë•ùëôùëúsubscriptùëîùëèùëÉùë•H(X)=-\sum_{x\in X}P(x)log_{b}P(x) (10)

Jensen-Divergence is estimated using the Kullback-Leibler divergence (KL-divergence). KL-divergence also measures the distance between two distributions. However, it is not symmetric and does not satisfy the triangle inequality. Jensen-Divergence is an approach that improves upon the KL-divergence, as it is symmetric and a smoothed version of KL-divergence. KL divergence between two distributions pùëùp and qùëûq is given as:

DK‚ÄãL(p||q)=‚à´‚àí‚àû‚àûp(x)log(p‚Äã(x)q‚Äã(x))dxD_{KL}(p||q)=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}p(x)log\left(\frac{p(x)}{q(x)}\right)dx (11)

Jensen-Divergence between two distributions pùëùp and qùëûq is given as:

JSD(p||q)=12(DK‚ÄãL(p||m)+DK‚ÄãL(q||m))JSD(p||q)=\frac{1}{2}\left(D_{KL}(p||m)+D_{KL}(q||m)\right) (12)

Thus, number of malicious clients equals 6 (nùíúsubscriptùëõùíún_{\mathcal{A}} = 6). For P‚ÄãM‚ÄãRùëÉùëÄùëÖPMR analysis, we test P‚ÄãM‚ÄãR‚àà{0.2,0.3,0.5}ùëÉùëÄùëÖ0.20.30.5PMR\in\{0.2,0.3,0.5\}, i.e., when nùíúsubscriptùëõùíún_{\mathcal{A}} equals 6, 9, and 15 and set non-IID = 0.7. As illustrated in Fig.¬†13 and Fig.¬†14, the M‚Äãa‚ÄãxJ‚ÄãDiùëÄùëésuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùêΩùê∑ùëñMax_{JD}^{i} value for benign clients differs significantly from that of malicious clients. Hence, BayBFed easily filters out all the malicious client updates, achieving a B‚ÄãAùêµùê¥BA of zero while keeping the M‚ÄãAùëÄùê¥MA of the global model intact.

Appendix F Additional adaptive attack

To implement an adaptive attack in which an adversary makes small changes to client updates to keep the JD divergences small, we vary the Poisoned Data Rate (PDR) to demonstrate the increment in the client updates for the CIFAR-10 dataset. We choose PDR to implement such an adaptive attack because arbitrary increments in PDR will also reflect the random increments in the client updates. Then, we compute the T‚ÄãP‚ÄãRùëáùëÉùëÖTPR, T‚ÄãN‚ÄãRùëáùëÅùëÖTNR, B‚ÄãAùêµùê¥BA, and M‚ÄãAùëÄùê¥MA metrics to evaluate the effectiveness of BayBFed compared against the no-defense B‚ÄãAùêµùê¥BA and M‚ÄãAùëÄùê¥MA, for different PDR values. We conduct experiments for three cases: a) PDR ‚àà\in (0.1,0.75) with an increment of 0.1, b) PDR ‚àà\in (0.01,0.1) with an increment of 0.01, and c) PDR ‚àà\in (0.1,0.2) with an increment of 0.01. Case a) demonstrates the impact of large PDR increments on the metrics mentioned above. The B‚ÄãAùêµùê¥BA with no defense remains at zero for the initial PDR values of 0.01 and 0.1, and after that, it starts to increase. BayBFed easily identified all the poisoned updates, thus filtering out all the poisoned updates, achieving a B‚ÄãAùêµùê¥BA of zero while keeping the M‚ÄãAùëÄùê¥MA of the global model intact. As we observed in case a), the no-defense B‚ÄãAùêµùê¥BA remains zero at PDR = 0.1 and starts to increase after that; we conducted two more experiments for PDR ‚àà\in (0,0.1) and PDR ‚àà\in (0.1,0.2) to analyze BayBFed‚Äôs performance when the PDR increases. Case b) demonstrates the impact of very small increments in PDR, and the no defense B‚ÄãAùêµùê¥BA remains at zero in this case. Nevertheless, BayBFed was correctly able to identify all the poisoned updates. In the case of c), the no defense B‚ÄãAùêµùê¥BA starts to increase from PDR = 0.11, and BayBFed again correctly identified all the poisoned updates, thus achieving a B‚ÄãAùêµùê¥BA of zero while keeping the M‚ÄãAùëÄùê¥MA of the global model intact. This experimental analysis demonstrates that even when a shrewd adversary makes small iterative changes to PDR (in consequence, client updates), BayBFed works efficiently by identifying all the poisoned updates.
